description.narrative:
Plan Sverige har ansökt om 32 144 597 SEK för att implementera en fas 2 av "The African Children's Charter Project" (ACCP) i Afrika under åren 2018-2020. Genom att främja implementeringen av den afrikanska barnrättskonventionen syftar projektet till att bidra till en långsiktig förbättring av barns liv i Afrika. Detta kommer att ske genom att 1) stärka kapaciteten hos den Afrikanska expertkommitté som är knuten till den afrikanska barnrättskonventionen, "The African Committee of Experts on the Right and Welfare of the Child" (ACERWC), 2) integrera barns rättigheter i beslut och verksamhet inom den Afrikanska Unionen (AU) och 3) stötta civilsamhället att arbeta tillsammans med AU för att främja och skydda barns rättigheter och välmående.
Sida är ensam bidragsgivare till projektet och har tidigare stöttat en första fas av ACCP (2011-2014) samt en överbryggningsperiod åren 2015-2017. Större delen av projektets aktiviteter kommer att utföras av ett konsortium som bildats under projektets första fas. I konsortiet ingår förutom Plan Sverige och Plans Pan-Afrikanska kontor i Etiopien, Svenska Rädda Barnen och Rädda Barnens kontor i Kenya och Senegal, The Dullah Omar Institute for Constitutional Law, Governance and Human Rights (Sydafrika), The African Child Policy Forum (Etiopien) och The Institute for Human Rights and Development in Africa (Gambia). ACERWC stöttas också via ett projekt finansierat a Europeiska Unionen. De båda projekten samordnas för ökad effektivitet och genomslag.

Plan Sweden has applied to Sida for funding of 32 144 597 SEK to carry out a phase 2 of the "African Children's Charter Project" (ACCP) during the period 2018-2020. By promoting the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child, the project aspires to contribute to a long-term improvement of children's life on the African continent. This will be done by 1) strengthening the capacity of the African Committee of Experts on the Rights and Welfare of the Child (ACERWC), 2) integrating children's rights in decisions and actions within the African Union and 3) supporting the civil society to work together with the African Union to promote and protect children's rights and welfare.
Sida will be the project's only funder and has previously supported a first phase of the ACCP (2011-2014) as well as a bridging period between 2015-2017. A great majority of the project's activities will be implemented by a consortium of non-governmental organisations which was formed during ACCP in phase 1. The consortium consist Plan Sweden and Plan's Pan-African Office in Ethiopia, Swedish Save the Children and ave the Childrens' offices in Kenya and Senegal, the Dullah Omar Institute for Constitutional Law, Governance and Human Rights (South Africa), the African Child Policy Forum (Ethiopia) and the Institute for Human Rights and Development in Africa (Gambia). ACERWC is also supported by a project funded by the European Union. The projects are coordinated for enhanced efficiency and impact.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

description.narrative: A mid-term review has been finalized and submitted to the Embassy. The review has captured the achievements of the project over the past 9 years, this phase being the last, thus, it has intentionally been given both formative and summative nature. The Embassy has also received an extensive narrative report of the project for 2019. Both the review by an external consultant and the annual narrative report indicate strong result achievement by the ACCP consortium under all the project objectives. Overall, the project has contributed to the achievement of the project goal through contributing to the strengthening of the human and technical capacity of the ACERWC, which has resulted in enhanced quality and turnaround times for issuance of Concluding Observations, General Comments and review of Communications submitted to the Committee. The Committee’s visibility has also been enhanced, with its Communications function strengthened. This additional human resources had therefore enabled the Committee to reach out to more stakeholders and more children and CSOs will become aware of the various mechanisms to engage with the Committee to further the implementation of the Charter. The project has also contributed to the consistent engagement of ACERWC and project partners with the AU Peace Support Operations Division (PSOD) and created a forum for discourse and action on addressing conflict in Africa through the continental conference on CAAC. Initiatives under ACCP have also contributed to one of the project objectives on promoting the integration of children’s rights in the decisions and actions of relevant AU bodies. This was done through promoting and facilitating enhanced and systematic collaboration between the ACERWC and RECS, ACHPR, AfCHPR, PRC and the PSC. As watch dogs for the implementation of the ACRWC, the project’s support to the CSO Forum and CSO coalitions and networks operating at different levels has also contributed to increased and consistent engagement of civil society with the ACERWC and other AU organs and AU Member States. One key setback during the period under review is the reduction in the number of State Parties reporting to the ACERWC. Various factors have been identified as causing the reduction in the number of State Party Reports being submitted including lack of capacity to develop quality reports among State Parties, lack of financial resources and lack of political goodwill by States to submit their periodic reports. ACCP consortium members plan to continue supporting CSOs to advocate for timely reporting by States.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
